Award.AwardTitle: Biochemical and Biophysical Mechanisms of Hydroid Allorecognition
Award.AbstractNarration: Colonial animals such as sponges, hydroids, corals, and ascidians can discriminate between their own tissues and those of other members of their species based on cellular contact, leading to a response in which they either fuse or reject. This phenomenon, called allorecognition, is controlled by genetic systems encoding highly variable allorecognition molecules. Despite their importance to the life histories of colonial organisms, the biochemical and biophysical basis of these invertebrate allorecognition systems remains poorly understood. The goal of this project is to elucidate these mechanisms in the cnidarian, Hydractinia symbiolongicarpus. In Hydractinia, allorecognition is controlled by two highly variable genes, alr1 and alr2. In this project the investigators will use a combination of in vitro biochemical assays and in vivo genetic approaches with transgenic animals to identify extracellular and intracellular ligands for the alr proteins and to characterize their role in cell signaling. These results will explain how the alr proteins, by themselves discriminate self from non-self, and how they signal allorecognition effector systems. Data generated will also enable comparisons to other self-recognition systems, including plant self-incompatibility loci and fungal mating type loci. Within animals, if homology is discovered between the Hydractinia allorecognition system and the ascidian allorecognition system or the vertebrate immune system, it would suggest that extant self-recognition systems evolved from a system present in the last common ancestor of all metazoans. This project will include training opportunities for undergraduate, graduate, and post-doctoral students, research opportunities for area high school students, and educational outreach to middle and elementary school students in southwestern Pennsylvania. Results of this work will be incorporated into undergraduate and graduate immunology courses at the University of Pittsburgh, as well as presentations and a newsletter for transplant patients at the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Colonial invertebrates--animals like sponges, corals, and sea squirts--live as encrustations on marine surfaces. As they grow, they expand across their substrate and frequently encounter other members of their own species. These encounters initiate a natural self/non-self recognition event. If the colonies are incompatible they compete for space, often aggressively. If the colonies are compatible, either because they are closely related or are, in fact, genetically identical fragments originating from the same colony, they will instead peacefully coexist, often fusing together to become a single colony. The ubiquity of these phenomena as mediators of competition in marine environments, coupled with their obvious analogy to immunological processes like transplant rejection and maternal-fetal tolerance, has led to a broad interest in the molecular basis of invertebrate allorecognition. A key question in the field is how colonial animals are capable of accurately distinguishing self tissues from literally hundreds of potential competitors within their environment. In this project, we have answered this question for the cnidarian, Hydractinia symbiolongicarpus, which is one of the only model systems of invertebrate allorecognition. Allorecognition in Hydractinia is controlled by two linked genes, Alr1 and Alr2, each of which encodes a transmembrane protein with an ectodomain bearing sequence similarity to immunoglobulin-like domains. These ectodomains are highly polymorphic, with hundreds of allelic isoforms present in Hydractinia populations. We have discovered that each isoform of an Alr1 or Alr2 protein is able to bind to itself homophilically across opposing cell membranes. Moreover, isoforms only bind to those with identical or highly similar sequences. This work has revealed the first biochemical mechanism for self/non-self discrimination in any invertebrate allorecognition system. It also suggests a potentially novel mechanism for protein-protein interactions between members of the immunoglobulin superfamily, a protein family present throughout metazoans.

 

Broader impacts of this project include research training for two postdoctoral fellows, one graduate student, three undergraduate students, and four high school students, three of which were members of underrepresented minorities in STEM fields. Each high school student carried out a semester or year-long independent research project and has gone on to major in a STEM related field in college. In addition, we designed and implemented an educational program that allowed more than 200 fourth and fifth graders in southwestern Pennsylvania to learn about animal diversity through hands-on activities with live Hydractinia colonies. In addition to presenting our work at scientific conferences, we also shared our research with two non-traditional audiences: fans attending tailgates prior to University of Pittsburgh football games and transplant patients who toured our lab in the School of Medicine.
